title: 114_hr2324
content: The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" allows for special conveyance authority regarding small parcels of national forest system land and public lands. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines terms like adjacent landholder, Director concerned, and eligible Federal lands parcel, which includes specific criteria for parcels of National Forest System land or public lands eligible for purchase. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" outlines criteria for eligible Federal lands parcels, including requirements that the land does not infringe on existing rights, lacks exceptional resources, and is not habitat for endangered species. It also defines terms like exceptional resource and Indian tribe. The "National Forest System land" is defined as land within the National Forest System, excluding certain designated areas managed by the Forest Service. The term "public lands" refers to land managed by the Bureau of Land Management, excluding specific designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. The term "public lands" refers to land managed by the Bureau of Land Management, excluding specific designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. In the context of conveyance, eligible Federal lands parcels can be selected for conveyance in response to a request from an adjacent landholder or upon recommendation from the Bureau of Land Management or National Forest System. The term "Regional Forester concerned" refers to the Regional Forester with jurisdiction over the National Forest System land of a specific Forest Service Region. Adjacent landholders can request to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels through a process created by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. The process must be consistent with other public purchase request processes, open to the public, and available online within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Adjacent landholders can request to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels through a process created by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. The Director or Regional Forester will review the parcel within 30 days to determine if it meets the criteria for conveyance. If the parcel does not meet the requirements, the landowner will receive a written explanation for the rejection. The process for requesting to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels includes a written explanation for rejection if the parcel fails to meet criteria, along with an opportunity to appeal. A conveyed parcel cannot exceed 160 acres without approval from the Director concerned. The process for acquiring eligible Federal lands parcels limits the size to 160 acres unless approved for additional acreage by the Director or Regional Forester. An adjacent landholder can only acquire one parcel per year, with the option for more if each parcel is under 160 acres. Public notice is required for the availability of parcels, even if they share boundaries with non-Federal land. The process for acquiring eligible Federal lands parcels limits the size to 160 acres unless approved for additional acreage by the Director or Regional Forester. An adjacent landholder can only acquire one parcel per year, with the option for more if each parcel is under 160 acres. Public notice is required for the availability of parcels, even if they share boundaries with non-Federal land. The notice shall state that the parcel satisfies the definition of eligible Federal lands parcel for conveyance. If the eligible Federal lands parcel shares a boundary with only a single parcel of non-Federal land or with multiple parcels owned by the same adjacent landholder, a negotiated sale will be carried out. If multiple parcels of non-Federal land, owned by different adjacent landholders, share a boundary with an eligible public lands parcel, the sale shall be conducted using competitive bidding procedures. The Director or Regional Forester may reject any offer that does not meet the minimum consideration. The Regional Forester may reject offers below the minimum consideration required. The purchaser must comply with local land use ordinances. Eligible Federal lands parcels are conveyed by quitclaim deed. An appeals process is available for decisions made by the Director concerned. The appeals process is available for reconsideration of rejected requests or offers for the sale of National Forest System land or public lands. The administering official for the appeals process is the Director concerned or the Regional Forester concerned. Fair market value is the consideration for the sale of eligible Federal lands parcels. The fair market value of an eligible Federal lands parcel must be paid in cash for the sale, as determined by an appraisal submitted by the adjacent landholder, with a rejection process in place if necessary. In accordance with regulations, funds collected from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels are deposited into a special Treasury fund. These funds are distributed annually to States where the Federal Government owns more than 33% of the land area. Funds collected from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels are distributed to States based on a 50-50 split, with half going to the State where the conveyance took place and the other half divided equally among the remaining States. States receiving funds must use them for purchasing additional eligible Federal lands parcels or complying with specific Federal requirements. The Director or Regional Forester must require the purchaser to pay for all costs associated with the conveyance of federal lands, including survey, appraisal, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected from the purchaser will be refunded. The Director or Regional Forester must refund any excess amount collected from the purchaser for the conveyance of federal lands. Amounts received as reimbursement will be credited to the fund used for covering costs and will be available for the same purposes. The conveyance process should be completed within 18 months, and it is categorically excluded from the requirement for an environmental assessment. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels under this section is exempt from environmental assessment requirements under the National Environmental Policy Act. This conveyance authority is in addition to the sale authority provided by the Federal Land Policy and Management Act.
